title: A People’s Vote is still better than Boris Johnson’s Brexit deal
text:
A People’s Vote is still the clearest alternative (Picture: Leon Neal/Getty Images)

It is now more than 1,200 days since the referendum that split our United Kingdom apart. Ever since that vote, I have been campaigning for the public to have the final say in a confirmatory referendum on any Brexit deal that emerges.

At first, it was a lonely position to hold in Parliament. However, thanks to the incredible campaigning, organising, marching, tweeting and letter writing from pro-European activists, a People’s Vote is now supported by all opposition parties in Parliament, as well as a growing number of Conservatives.

Boris Johnson wants MPs and the public to be cornered into thinking it’s his deal or no-deal at all, but that’s a false choice.

While the proposals may have been agreed with the EU it’s by no means certain that it will pass in Parliament. Whatever happens, a People’s Vote is the obvious way forward.

This week I met with senior diplomats and the European Parliament’s Brexit Steering Group in Brussels, as part of a delegation with a cross-party group with senior MPs from all Westminster parties except the DUP.

Despite obvious fatigue after years of political turmoil resulting from the 2016 referendum, all the European politicians and diplomats I met stressed their commitment to being patient and working in the best interests of UK and EU27 citizens.

There was a shared recognition of the gravity of the situation: with jobs, trade, workers’ rights, environmental, social and protections and our 28 nations’ security at risk.

As Nelson Mandela said, ‘the real makers of history are the ordinary men and women of our country’.

During those meetings it emerged that a full and final deal is very unlikely to be ratified by all sides in time for Boris Johnson’s ‘do or die’ 31 October deadline.

If the deal is voted in down by MPs on Saturday, The Benn Act will require the government to request an extension.

European politicians and officials were open to the idea of either a short technical extension, or a longer extension to allow for a democratic moment to break the deadlock.

We were left in no doubt that if Parliament were to express a will to hold a new referendum, the EU would grant a suitably lengthy extension period.

The job left for us is to convince a dozen or so undecided MPs to back a People’s Vote. This will not be easy, but it is achievable.

Advertisement

I know several MPs who were once opposed to another referendum but who have since changed their mind because of the number of letters and emails they received from their constituents calling on them to support giving the choice on Brexit back to the people.

As Nelson Mandela said, ‘the real makers of history are the ordinary men and women of our country’. So email your MP, write to them, meet with them, encourage them, and support them in making the right decision. That’s what it means to live in a democracy.

The biggest opportunity to convince MPs to back a People’s Vote will happen this Saturday. Hundreds of thousands of activists will gather for the Together for the Final Say march in Westminster.

This will be the first time Parliament has sat during a People’s Vote march on this scale.

It will be an opportunity to tell all MPs what kind of country we want to be. We will march against the narrow-minded, isolationist, nostalgic version of Little England that Boris Johnson promotes.

We will rally for the open-minded, inclusive, internationalist, progressive United Kingdom we know we can be.

That is why Saturday’s march is so important – it’s a chance for the people to show the Brexit elite in government that they do not speak for the people. That we are the people and that, together, we must have the final say.
